title: Stable Matchings with Restricted Preferences: Structure and Complexity

sections.discussion and questions: Our kğ‘˜k-bounded model is equivalent to SM instances defined on (bipartite) graphs with maximum degree at most kğ‘˜k. Thus TheoremÂ 4.2 implies that #â€‹SM#SM\mathrm{\#SM} remains #â€‹BIS#BIS\mathrm{\#BIS}-complete even when restricted to graphs with maximum degree 333. Since graphs with maximum degree 222 (i.e., 222-bounded instances) are disjoint unions of paths and cycles, #â€‹SM#SM\mathrm{\#SM} can be solved on 222-bounded instances in polynomial time. (Paths have unique stable matchings, and each cycle can support 111 or 222 stable matchings.) Thus #â€‹SM#SM\mathrm{\#SM} has a sharp hardness threshold in the kğ‘˜k-bounded model at k=3ğ‘˜3k=3. Interestingly, #â€‹BIS#BIS\mathrm{\#BIS} shows a similar threshold around k=6ğ‘˜6k=6: counting independent sets in bipartite graphs of maximum degree kâ‰¥6ğ‘˜6k\geq 6 is #â€‹BIS#BIS\mathrm{\#BIS}-completeÂ , while instances of maximum degree kâ‰¤5ğ‘˜5k\leq 5 admit an FPRAS, even if vertices on only one side of the bipartition obey the degree boundÂ . Recently, Curticapean et al.Â  considered other parameterized variants of #â€‹BIS#BIS\mathrm{\#BIS}, and showed that the variants admit efficient fixed-parameter algorithms in bounded-degree graphs. It would be interesting to see if #â€‹SM#SM\mathrm{\#SM} becomes easy in any â€œnaturalâ€ restricted graph class. For what families of (bipartite) graphs can #â€‹SM#SM\mathrm{\#SM} be computed or approximated efficiently? Can #â€‹SM#SM\mathrm{\#SM} be efficiently computed in planar graphs? Graphs of bounded genus? What rotation posets can be realized by these restricted instances? It seems likely that planar SM instances (i.e., instances where the graph GğºG of acceptable partners is planar) realize a restricted family of rotation posets. To see why, note that every rotation corresponds to a cycle in GğºG, and a rotation ÏğœŒ\rho can be immediate predecessor of Ïâ€²superscriptğœŒâ€²\rho^{\prime} only if either the corresponding cycles intersect, or there is an edge connecting a node in one cycle to a node in another. This restriction seems to limit what rotation posets are realizable by planar instances. For example, we believe that a poset ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P} whose Hasse diagram is a sufficiently large complete bipartite graph minus a perfect matching cannot be realized by any planar instance. Does the family of rotation posets realized by planar SM instances admit a clean description? Can such a characterization be used to solve structural SM problems more efficiently than the general case? The kğ‘˜k-attribute, (k1,k2)subscriptğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘˜2(k_{1},k_{2})-list, and kğ‘˜k-range preference models can also be used to describe SMI instancesâ€”that is, SM instances with incomplete preferences. Specifically, an SMI instance arising from one of these models is an instance for which every preference list is a sub-list of an instance in the model with complete preferences. Our construction for the (k1,k2)subscriptğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘˜2(k_{1},k_{2})-list model in SectionÂ 5 has the property that there are two master preferences for each gender such that all (incomplete) preference lists are sub-lists of one of the two master lists. Thus, every finite poset is realizable in the SMI variant of the (2,2)22(2,2)-list model. Since complete preferences are a special case of SMI instances, our kğ‘˜k-attribute construction also implies that SMI kğ‘˜k-attribute preferences realize all finite posets. What rotation posets can be realized in the SMI variant of the kğ‘˜k-range model? These restricted preference models can also be generalized to allow for preferences with ties: that is, an agent may be indifferent to a choice of several partners. It is well-known that many stable marriage problems become intractible in instances with both incomplete preferences and ties (see, e.g.,Â ). Consider SM instances with ties and incomplete preferences. What stable matching problems remain NP-hard when restricted to instances arising from the kğ‘˜k-attribute, (k1,k2)subscriptğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘˜2(k_{1},k_{2})-list, or kğ‘˜k-range models? TheoremÂ 4.7 characterizes the rotation posets realized in the kğ‘˜k-attribute model for kâ‰¥6ğ‘˜6k\geq 6, but does not say anything about Attrâ¡(k)Attrğ‘˜\operatorname{Attr}(k) for kâ‰¤5ğ‘˜5k\leq 5. What rotation posets are realized by Attrâ¡(k)Attrğ‘˜\operatorname{Attr}(k) for k=2,3,â€¦,5ğ‘˜23â€¦5k=2,3,\ldots,5? We conjecture that Attrâ¡(k)Attrğ‘˜\operatorname{Attr}(k) realizes arbitrary rotation posets for any kâ‰¥3ğ‘˜3k\geq 3. This conjecture is consistent with the results of Chebolu et al.Â , who show that #â€‹SM#SM\mathrm{\#SM} is #â€‹BIS#BIS\mathrm{\#BIS}-complete in the kğ‘˜k-attributed model for any kâ‰¥3ğ‘˜3k\geq 3. Our use of cyclic polytopes in SectionÂ 4.2 to establish TheoremÂ 4.7 is wasteful in the sense that cyclic polytopes give much stronger guarantees than our result actually requires. Indeed, the construction allows us to embed any 222-dimensional simplicial complex into ğ‘6superscriptğ‘6\mathbf{R}^{6} in convex position. However, our argument only requires that the 222-dimensional faces of the complexes corresponding to preference lists output by ğ–¢ğ—ˆğ—‡ğ—Œğ—ğ—‹ğ—ğ–¼ğ—ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ—Œğ—ğ–ºğ—‡ğ–¼ğ–¾ğ–¢ğ—ˆğ—‡ğ—Œğ—ğ—‹ğ—ğ–¼ğ—ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ—Œğ—ğ–ºğ—‡ğ–¼ğ–¾\mathsf{ConstructInstance} be embedded in convex position. Thus it seems that a more careful analysis of the output of ğ–¢ğ—ˆğ—‡ğ—Œğ—ğ—‹ğ—ğ–¼ğ—ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ—Œğ—ğ–ºğ—‡ğ–¼ğ–¾ğ–¢ğ—ˆğ—‡ğ—Œğ—ğ—‹ğ—ğ–¼ğ—ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ—Œğ—ğ–ºğ—‡ğ–¼ğ–¾\mathsf{ConstructInstance} could establish TheoremÂ 4.7 for smaller values of kğ‘˜k. Chebolu et al.Â  and KÃ¼nnemann et al.Â 2 also consider the kğ‘˜k-Euclidean preference model defined by Bogomolnaia and LaslierÂ . In this model, each agent is also associated with a point in ğ‘ksuperscriptğ‘ğ‘˜\mathbf{R}^{k}. Preferences are determined by the Euclidean distance between the points: ağ‘a prefers agents in order b1,b2,â€¦,bnsubscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›b_{1},b_{2},\ldots,b_{n} where b1subscriptğ‘1b_{1} is ağ‘aâ€™s nearest agent, b2subscriptğ‘2b_{2} the second nearest, and so on. Chebolu et al.Â  showed that #â€‹SM#SM\mathrm{\#SM} is #â€‹BIS#BIS\mathrm{\#BIS} complete in the kğ‘˜k-Euclidean model for kâ‰¥2ğ‘˜2k\geq 2. What rotation posets are realized in the kğ‘˜k-Euclidean model? We suspect that kğ‘˜k-Euclidean preferences realize arbitrary posets for a relatively small fixed constant kğ‘˜k. KÃ¼nnemann et al.Â 2 also consider an asymmetric version of the kğ‘˜k-Euclidean model in which each agent ağ‘a has two associated points in Rksuperscriptğ‘…ğ‘˜R^{k}: a position xâ†’asubscriptâ†’ğ‘¥ğ‘\vec{x}_{a} and an opinion yâ†’asubscriptâ†’ğ‘¦ğ‘\vec{y}_{a}. The agent ağ‘a ranks agents in order of their positionâ€™s distance to ağ‘aâ€™s opinion. That is ağ‘a ranks b1subscriptğ‘1b_{1} with yâ†’b1subscriptâ†’ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘1\vec{y}_{b_{1}} closest to xâ†’asubscriptâ†’ğ‘¥ğ‘\vec{x}_{a} first, and so on. Our 666-attribute construction can be modified to realize arbitrary rotation posets in the asymmetric 666-Euclidean model. In the modified construction, the positions of each mâˆˆMğ‘šğ‘€m\in M and wâˆˆWğ‘¤ğ‘Šw\in W are the same as the embedding in SectionÂ 4.2 (i.e., each agent corresponds to a vertex of a cyclic polytope). If m1,m2,m3subscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š2subscriptğ‘š3m_{1},m_{2},m_{3} appear on wğ‘¤wâ€™s preference list in the 333-bounded instance constructed by ğ–¢ğ—ˆğ—‡ğ—Œğ—ğ—‹ğ—ğ–¼ğ—ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ—Œğ—ğ–ºğ—‡ğ–¼ğ–¾ğ–¢ğ—ˆğ—‡ğ—Œğ—ğ—‹ğ—ğ–¼ğ—ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ—Œğ—ğ–ºğ—‡ğ–¼ğ–¾\mathsf{ConstructInstance}, then she can choose her opinion xâ†’wsubscriptâ†’ğ‘¥ğ‘¤\vec{x}_{w} so that (the positions of) xâ†’m1subscriptâ†’ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘š1\vec{x}_{m_{1}}, xâ†’m2subscriptâ†’ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘š2\vec{x}_{m_{2}}, and xâ†’m3subscriptâ†’ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘š3\vec{x}_{m_{3}} are the three closest positions to xâ†’wsubscriptâ†’ğ‘¥ğ‘¤\vec{x}_{w} as follows. Let câ†’wsubscriptâ†’ğ‘ğ‘¤\vec{c}_{w} denote the circumcenter of the triangle in the plane determined by xâ†’m1subscriptâ†’ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘š1\vec{x}_{m_{1}}, xâ†’m2subscriptâ†’ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘š2\vec{x}_{m_{2}}, and xâ†’m3subscriptâ†’ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘š3\vec{x}_{m_{3}}, and let Î²â†’wâˆˆğ‘6subscriptâ†’ğ›½ğ‘¤superscriptğ‘6\vec{\beta}_{w}\in\mathbf{R}^{6} be the vector defined immediately afterÂ (1), so that âˆ’Î²â†’wsubscriptâ†’ğ›½ğ‘¤-\vec{\beta}_{w} is an outward facing normal vector for the plane containing xâ†’m1,m2subscriptâ†’ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š2\vec{x}_{m_{1}},m_{2}, and m3subscriptğ‘š3m_{3}. Thus, for any point pâˆˆğ‘6ğ‘superscriptğ‘6p\in\mathbf{R}^{6} of the form yâ†’=câ†’wâˆ’tâ€‹Î²â†’wâ†’ğ‘¦subscriptâ†’ğ‘ğ‘¤ğ‘¡subscriptâ†’ğ›½ğ‘¤\vec{y}=\vec{c}_{w}-t\vec{\beta}_{w} with tâˆˆğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘t\in\mathbf{R}, the points m1,m2subscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š2m_{1},m_{2} and m3subscriptğ‘š3m_{3} are all equidistant from yâ†’â†’ğ‘¦\vec{y}. By choosing tğ‘¡t sufficiently large, we can ensure that, in fact, xâ†’m1subscriptâ†’ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘š1\vec{x}_{m_{1}}, xâ†’m2subscriptâ†’ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘š2\vec{x}_{m_{2}} and xâ†’m3subscriptâ†’ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘š3\vec{x}_{m_{3}} are the three closest points in Mğ‘€M to yâ†’â†’ğ‘¦\vec{y}. By taking yâ†’wsubscriptâ†’ğ‘¦ğ‘¤\vec{y}_{w} to be a slight perturbation of such a yâ†’â†’ğ‘¦\vec{y}, we can ensure that for all mâ‰ m1,m2,m3ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š2subscriptğ‘š3m\neq m_{1},m_{2},m_{3}, we have That is, wğ‘¤w ranks m1subscriptğ‘š1m_{1}, m2subscriptğ‘š2m_{2}, and m3subscriptğ‘š3m_{3} (in that order) ahead of all other men. As with the 666-attribute case, repeating the procedure for all men and women is sufficient to prove that the corresponding asymmetric 666-Euclidean instance realizes the same rotation poset as the underlying 333-bounded instance. While TheoremÂ 5.3 characterizes the rotation posets realizable by (k1,âˆ)subscriptğ‘˜1(k_{1},\infty)-list SM instances, it does not say anything about (k1,k2)subscriptğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘˜2(k_{1},k_{2})-list preferences for constant k2subscriptğ‘˜2k_{2}, nor the original kğ‘˜k-list preference structure of Bhatnagar et al.Â . What rotation posets can be realized in the (k1,k2)subscriptğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘˜2(k_{1},k_{2})-list model for k1,k2<nsubscriptğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘˜2ğ‘›k_{1},k_{2}<n? We suspect that for k1=k2=2subscriptğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘˜22k_{1}=k_{2}=2, the rotation poset is restricted, but we are unsure of how to prove even this seemingly simple fact. We note that KÃ¼nnemann et al.Â 2 had similar difficulty with the kğ‘˜k-range model, and posed as an open question whether or not 222-list preferences admit an oâ€‹(n2)ğ‘œsuperscriptğ‘›2o(n^{2})-time algorithm for finding a stable matching. Our construction in the proof of TheoremÂ 7.9 shows that every kğ‘˜k-range instance has a rotation poset whose pathwidth is at most 50â€‹k250superscriptğ‘˜250k^{2}. Can this bound be improved? What is the maximum pathwidth of â„›â€‹(I)â„›ğ¼\mathcal{R}(I) for IâˆˆRangeâ¡(k)ğ¼Rangeğ‘˜I\in\operatorname{Range}(k)? Is it Î©â€‹(k2)Î©superscriptğ‘˜2\Omega(k^{2})? Or can our Oâ€‹(k2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2O(k^{2}) upper bound be imporved to, say, Oâ€‹(k)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜O(k)? The stable marriage problem has a natural interpretation as a distributed problem, where each agent is represented by a processor and agents communicate via point-to-point communication. In fact, the Gale-Shapley algorithmÂ 5 has a natural interpretation in such a computational model. It is straightforward to show that finding a stable matching requires a number of rounds proportional to the network diameter, even when there are no constraints on local computation and communication (i.e., in the LOCAL model described inÂ 1). If bathdwidth is restricted to Oâ€‹(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n) bits per edge per communication round (i.e., the CONGEST modelÂ 1), finding a stable matching still requires Î©â€‹(n)Î©ğ‘›\Omega(\sqrt{n}) rounds, even in networks of diameter Oâ€‹(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n)Â . Can stable matchings be found faster in distributed models of computation if the preferences are restricted? Consider the distributed stable marriage problem in which each agent is represented by a processor. How many communication rounds are needed to find a stable matching if the preferences are assigned according to the kğ‘˜k-attribute, (k1,k2)subscriptğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘˜2(k_{1},k_{2})-list, or kğ‘˜k-range models? We note that â€œalmost stableâ€ matchings can be computed in Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1) rounds in bounded-degree networksÂ 4 and logOâ€‹(1)â¡(n)superscriptğ‘‚1ğ‘›\log^{O(1)}(n) rounds in general networksÂ 0. The work of Khanchandani and WattenhoferÂ  shows that stable matchings in the kğ‘˜k-range model can be computed with less total communication than the Gale-Shapley algorithm.
